Comment: A Ponzi scheme is a type of investment fraud where early investors are paid with funds from newer investors, rather than from legitimate profits. It works by creating a false impression of high returns from a seemingly legitimate business, while in reality, the scheme relies solely on attracting new investors to pay previous ones.

Comment: I think you may vastly underestimate the amount of people under 60 who get SSI.  It's disabled people, and the single parent of children with a deceased mother or father.  As of February [11,300,000 as of February are under retirement age. ](https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/quickfacts/stat_snapshot/)  I for example, have been considered disabled for over a decade.  I'm under 50.  I protest.  I run charity food drives. Now that I can't work, I get the fuck out there and make a difference.  I take my kids to protests and rallies.    This just doesn't affect old people.   Fortunately I have a bread winning spouse, and if I miss a month or two we will make it work.  I've been broke my whole life (due to my disabilities), I know how to cook for a family on a poverty budget.   I know where and how to get assistance from various nongovernmental sources.  I've done the paperwork for just about every type of assistance.    I'm not worried about me.   I'm worried, like you sa9d, about the people who can't stand up for themselves.   Like my father, my mother, my neighbors.     Ike I said, riots will be happening by the third missed payment if this happens.   And it won't be just the current protestors out there, we'll get another 100 million with us.

Comment: I’m still not sure what you thought was “silly” about what I said, because you haven’t actually addressed my point. Social Security isn’t a personal savings account like the original commenter seemed to imply. There’s no individual pot of money with your name on it to cash out later. What you pay now goes to current retirees. That’s all I was trying to clarify.  Instead of engaging with that, you pivoted to something unrelated. Talking about hypotheticals, like redirecting capital gains taxes into the trust fund, doesn’t change how the system functions right now. And it’s not relevant to the point I was making. Social Security is funded by payroll taxes from current workers, and those funds are used to pay current retirees. That’s not an opinion, it’s how the program is structured. A lot of people mistakenly believe they’re paying into their own personal account for the future. They’re not.  And the stuff about full retirement age and delayed benefits isn’t word play. The system is designed to encourage people to delay collecting by offering higher monthly payments if they wait. That’s how the benefit formula works.  Again, none of this actually responds to what I said. Social Security doesn’t function like a personal account, and none of us have a balance building up.
Author: Senior-Purchase-6961

Comment: Correct. Which is entirely different from Social Security for a myriad of reasons, as the link I just gave you explains.

Author: SnooChocolates1198

Comment: I’m still not sure why you took issue with my original comment. I wish you’d expand on it.  You haven’t explained what part of it was wrong. I just described how the system works. Current workers fund current retirees.  You keep pivoting to unrelated points. I never brought up retirement age, so I’m not even sure why we’re talking about it. Sure, you can adjust what’s labeled as the “full” retirement age, but that doesn’t change the fact that the system offers more if you delay collecting. That’s just how the benefit formula is set up.  And saying benefits are based on what you paid in doesn’t mean the money was saved for you. It just helps determine what you qualify for.  If it really worked like a personal account, how do you explain people like my mom who have already collected more than they paid in? That money comes from today’s workers. That’s why it’s called Social Security.  The whole point I made, the one you thought was just sooo silly, is that the money is not saved in an account for you specifically. That’s what people usually think when they talk about “paying in” and “cashing out”. It’s just not how it works and shows they fundamentally misunderstand it.
Author: Senior-Purchase-6961

Comment: > It explains nothing.  It lists several reasons, in detail, why Social Security is different than a Ponzi Scheme. What specifically do you disagree with?   >It's been a ponzi scheme for years.  Just because you keep saying this doesn't make it true.
Author: Blarfk

Comment: There are definitely structural parallels. Social Security relies on current workers to fund current retirees, which is similar to how a Ponzi scheme operates.  But the difference is in intent and transparency. Ponzi schemes are fraudulent and unsustainable by design. Social Security is a public, legal program with oversight, and the government can adjust taxes or payout to keep it going.  So while the comparison makes sense at a surface level, it’s not a scam or a scheme. That’s the important thing. Its a useful program for people who are getting too old to be in the workforce.
Author: Senior-Purchase-6961
